stream_context.summary: Kaze spends most of the session prototyping a new tropical-style water system for the overworld and briefly celebrates having rewritten Mario 64’s entire audio engine.

development_findings.summary: Kaze has almost finished a complete rewrite of Mario 64’s audio engine, making it far more memory-efficient and easier to debug.
development_findings.quote: Over the past week I spent a lot of time completely rewriting Mario 64's audio engine… It's a lot more memory efficient. I can do a few cool new things.

development_findings.summary: Only Nintendo’s RSP interface remains; once that is replaced, the new audio system will be legally independent for use in future, potentially original, games.
development_findings.quote: The interfacing with the RSP is still Nintendo's code… If we made this like our own game… as long as we remake the interface we’re fine legally.

development_findings.summary: The stream’s primary task is choosing textures and building a convincing, performance-friendly water solution for the overworld’s beach area.

After rejecting GameCube inspirations (Wind Waker, Sunshine) and Wave64 water, Kaze settles on a sine-wave system whose amplitude decreases near shore, driven by vertex distance from island center and rendered on a hex-tessellated mesh (~600 visible triangles).
development_findings.quote: Now the waves actually look properly going into the island… On the inside it's barely going up and down and on the outside we have gigantic waves.

development_findings.summary: Future improvements include dynamic shoreline foam, vertex-colour depth cues, palette unification, and optional floaties or pillars for the dock.
Return to Yoshi’s Island is targeting a 64 MB cart size and full N64 console compatibility, unlike many earlier Mario 64 hacks.
development_findings.quote: I'm not going with an 8 megabyte game, I'm going with 64 megabytes… Many romhacks are not console compatible. This one is.

development_findings.summary: Kaze labels the overworld as 'open zone'—no loading screens—rather than fully open-world, reflecting design intent.
development_findings.quote: It's all just going to feel open world, and there's not going to be loading zones. But… calling this an open world is maybe a little cringe.

context_findings.summary: Kaze mentions his nine-month-old baby, describing lighthearted parenting moments that occasionally affect stream timing.
context_findings.quote: My baby's favorite thing… is eating the remote.

context_findings.summary: He notes an unplanned 20-pound weight loss (215 → ~194 lbs) and personal avoidance of energy drinks.
Expresses frustration over argumentative YouTube comments on his recent RNG video and general ‘nonsense comments’.
context_findings.quote: I'm getting so many nonsense comments… this is the worst part about making a video.

context_findings.summary: Acknowledges Easter holiday; no stream the following day.
context_findings.quote: Tomorrow is Easter, and I will not be able to stream.

context_findings.summary: Reflects on Mario 64 hacking’s former reputation within the wider homebrew scene and his desire for higher standards.
context_findings.quote: For the longest time the Mario 64 community was like such a pathetic part of the homebrew community.

context_findings.summary: States his simple motivation for the game’s theme: he likes Yoshi.
context_findings.quote: I like Yoshi. That's kind of where the thought process ended.

biobak.summary: Provides real-time feedback on water approach (e.g., smoothing waves, handling swimming), which Kaze integrates into his decisions.

key_stories.title: Rewriting the Audio Engine
key_stories.summary: Kaze spent a week tearing out Mario 64’s original sound system and replacing it with his own, yielding better memory use and debuggability.
key_stories.challenge: Nintendo’s aging audio code was inefficient, opaque, and legally problematic for an original release.
key_stories.process: Studied the entire codebase, rewrote every component except the RSP interface, and optimised memory allocation.
key_stories.outcome: A near-complete, self-authored engine that can be fully legal once the RSP layer is also replaced.
key_stories.key_quote: Meaning it's going to be very easy to debug any problems that may occur.

key_stories.title: Taming the Tropical Water
key_stories.summary: The stream chronicles Kaze’s iterative search for a water solution that is visually rich yet performant on N64 hardware.
key_stories.challenge: Need waves that feel natural, point toward shore, avoid swimming glitches, and stay within triangle/CPU limits.
key_stories.process: Reviewed other games, rejected several methods, settled on a hex-tessellated sine system with distance-based amplitude and colour depth cues.
key_stories.outcome: Functional prototype with large outer swells, calm inner ripples; next steps are foam rendering and palette polish.
key_stories.key_quote: It's kind of crazy how easy it is to make a map look good if you just have good shaders… on emulator these are shaders, fuck you!
